importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date of the arrest and the incident at Hartsfield-Jackson Atlanta International Airport, highlighting a recent and active threat to public safety.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The time Cagle arrived at the airport, when surveillance video shows his arrival and interaction with TSA, indicating the critical moment of potential threat execution.

keyTakeAways: A man named Billy Joe Cagle, a 49-year-old convicted felon from Cartersville, Georgia, planned to shoot up Hartsfield-Jackson Atlanta International Airport via a social media livestream.
Cagle was identified by his family who reported his online threats and possession of an assault rifle, leading to his arrest at the airport.
The incident was averted due to early family intervention and law enforcement action, preventing a potential mass shooting.
Cagle was found with an AR-15 rifle and 27 rounds of ammunition in his Chevrolet pickup truck parked outside the terminal.

He has been charged with multiple offenses, including making terroristic threats, criminal attempt to commit aggravated assault, possession of a firearm during commission of a felony, and possession of a firearm by a felon.
Cagle had a history of mental health struggles, including schizophrenia and medication use, and was previously known in his community.
The city's police chief and mayor praised the role of community members and timely information sharing in preventing a tragedy.
Federal authorities are investigating how Cagle obtained the firearm, which law enforcement states he was not legally allowed to possess.

summaryOfNewsArticle: A 49-year-old convicted felon from Cartersville, Georgia, Billy Joe Cagle, was arrested at Hartsfield-Jackson Atlanta International Airport after his family alerted authorities that he had streamed on social media a plan to shoot up the airport. Police found an AR-15 rifle and 27 rounds of ammunition in his Chevrolet pickup truck parked outside the terminal. Cagle, who reportedly had schizophrenia and was taking medication, was charged with multiple violent and firearms-related offenses. The incident was averted due to early intervention by family members and law enforcement, with officials praising the role of public vigilance and community connections in preventing a potential mass shooting. Federal authorities are investigating how Cagle obtained the weapon, which law enforcement says he was not legally allowed to possess.
title: Man Arrested at Atlanta Airport After Social Media Threat to Shoot Up Terminal
